moves.1. e4: In this game, black (me) obtains major control of the game with a 7 or 8 point material advantage, but, the moral of the story, never give up!  Black makes a really, really bad move at 24 and allows white to knight fork its queen.  After that, things turned decidedly in white's favor.  White does an excellent job of executing the endgame.  White starts with the popular e4.
moves.1... c5: Black sets up the Sicilian, which is often an aggressive counter-attack.
moves.2. c3: I've come to learn from 1800  players that this is really smart.  I still don't know exactly why, but I guess it has to do with controlling the center 4 squares.
moves.3. d4: I usually like this because it gives me (black) the option to open up a hole in white's line.
moves.3... cxd4: Which I exercise immediately.  Obviously, white can respond with cxd4 to balance out the trade or place the queen in the middle of the board.  Some like this for white, but I think it can be a weakness as it gives black a big target and an opportunity to chase the queen and develop at the same time.
moves.5. Nf3:
According to the GK database, this is:
1. e4 c5 2. d4 cxd4 3. c3 Nc6 4. cxd4 e6 5. Nf3
B21: Sicilian, Smith-Morra gambit
(I just love these opening names.)
moves.5... g6: I liked the fianchetto here, as it puts stress on d4.
moves.6. Nc3: Three knights in play, pretty typical.
moves.6... Bg7: Equal pressure on d4 at this point.
moves.7. Be3: White regains the advantage on d4.
moves.7... Nge7: I think I'm worried about Nf6, as it might attract e5.  The problem here is that it hinders black's development opportunities.
moves.8. a3: Probably a wasted move on white's part.  I suppose it does prevent Nb4.
moves.9. Qd2: White looks to be in better position here.
moves.9... d5:
If white elected to capture, my responses would have been ...
10.	exd5 	Nxd5
11.	Nxd5 	Qxd5
12.	Bh6 	Bxh6
13.	Qxh6 	Nxd4
14.	Nxd4 	Qxd4
moves.10. e5: White opts to advance, which is generally a good move in this situation.
moves.10... Nf5: Now, Ne7 doesn't look so bad.  Puts direct pressure on the bishop and forces white to maintain support of d4.
moves.11. Bd3: White doesn't like the look things and sets up the possibility of a bishop-knight trade, one way or the other.
moves.12. Qxe3: The only move that doesn't compromise the short castle.
moves.13. b4: Na5 might have been interesting, but I think white was probably looking to force the Nc6 to act.
moves.14. exf6: If white doesn't take, white runs the risk of setting up a queen trade.  From white's perspective, this seems strong as it weakens black's castle.
moves.14... Bxf6: But, perhaps white missed the pressure this now places on d4.  Ne2 would be a logical response.
moves.15... Nxd4: So, black gains a pawn here.
moves.16... Nxf3+:
What I expected ...
17.	gxf3 	Bd4???
18.	Qe2 	Rf4???
19.	Na4 	Qd8???
moves.17. gxf3: Black is happy here with stacked pawns in the castle, so far so good.
moves.17... Bd4: Black is even happier.  Stacked bishop and queen on f2.  Trouble for white.
moves.18. Qh6: On the one hand, this puts pressure on the king and sets up some late-game possibilities (which, in this game, actually worked), but I wonder if this was too rash of a response to the impending black attack.  Qe2 would have been sufficient.
moves.21. Nf4: White appears to be eying a quick mate if he can get his knight into position.  Black eventually forgets about this knight to his own detriment.
moves.21... Be3:
I thought I saw a mate opportunity ...
22.	Rc-e1 	d4
23.	Nxd3 	Qc6 
24.	Rf3 	Qxf3#
CHECKMATE !
moves.22... d4: Building pressure in the middle of the board.
moves.23. Rxe3: An interesting sacrifice.  White seeks to pressure the king.
moves.23... Rxe3:
Black is up 8 points now.  At this point, I wrote myself a note:  "this is critical, be careful not to let your king get into check."  For some reason, I still managed to screw this up.
24.	Nxg6 	Qc6 
25.	Kg1 	Rf3
26.	Rxf3 	Qxf3
27.	Qf8  	Qxf8
28.	Nxf8 	Kxf8
moves.24. Nxg6: Obviously, I need to defend against the possibility of Qf8  .
moves.24... Qc6+:
I could have advanced the bishop to d7, I could have done any number of things.  Instead, I set myself up for a knight fork possibility.
25.	Kg1 	Rf3
26.	Ne7  	Kf7
27.	Nxc6 	Rxf1 
28.	Kxf1 	bxc6
moves.25. Kg1: Now, black's in a world of hurt with triple pressure on f8.
moves.27. Nxc6: Now, I'm down 2 and the king is exposed.
moves.27... Rxf1+: Normally, I wouldn't trade when behind, but I don't think another option existed at this point.
moves.29. Qxh7+: Back to even and in check.
moves.29... Kf6: Trying to protect the center pawns.
moves.31... Bd7: My note to myself at this point:  "---DO NOT LINE UP KING AND ROOK---."  Black is desperate.
moves.32... Kd6: Trying to get over to the right side of the board to help stop pawn promotion.
moves.33. h4: Which leaves a nice path for the h pawn.
moves.33... a5: Why trade when you're behind?  Bad move for black.
moves.34... Kc7: Black is just further abandoning the h file.
moves.36. Qxb4: This keeps the a pawn out of the way of the c pawn.
moves.36... Be8: Not much to be gained here, but it's an attempt to move things around.
moves.37. Qe7+: Smart check as it prevents any immediately possibility of black getting pieces into better position.
moves.37... Bd7: The only move for black that prevents further immediate losses.
moves.38... Re8:
My hopes at this point were as follows:
39.	Qf6 	Kd6
40.	h7 	Kc7
41.	h8=Q 	Rxh8
42.	Qxh8 	Kd6
moves.39. Qxe8: But white makes a smart sacrifice as I can't stop the pawn promotion.
moves.41. h8=Q: A masterful turn of events for white.  I'll speed things along now in the annotation.
moves.41... Bd7 42. a4 c5: Why not get the king over to the a file?
moves.43. a5 Bc6 44. a6 Kd5 45. a7 e5 46. a8=Q: Another smart sacrifice, since white has what he needs to finish off black.
moves.48. Qc6+ Kf5 49. Qxc5 Ke4 50. Ke2 Kf4 51: Black makes succinct moves to isolate the pawn.
moves.53... Ke6 54. Kxe4 Ke7: The rest is just good solid use of the queen-king tandem.  Nice comeback sf115!
Again, well executed by white.  gg
